author: english.ahram.org.eg
title: Top British military officials in Cairo to discuss counter-terrorism - Politics - Egypt
text:
Related UK won't leave Egypt to stand alone against terrorism: Ambassador A British military delegation arrived in Cairo on Friday for a two-day visit to discuss counter-terrorism efforts with Egyptian military officials.
The delegation is headed by Lieutenant General John Lorimer, who as Chief of Joint Operations has a brief to oversee and control Britain's overseas operations.
Egyptâ€™s chief of defence staff, Lieutenant General Mahmoud Hegazy, visited London two weeks ago where he and senior British military officials discussed the role the UK can play in supporting Egypt in effective counter-terrorism work, and how to cooperate to secure a stable future for Libya.
He also visited Longmoor military training camp, where 15 Egyptian officers are currently receiving "close protection training" from the British army.
In August, Hegazy met with a British delegation in Cairo headed by the UK's national security advisor John Jenkins where officials discussed mutual interests including what they call "the war on terrorism", and regional developments.
This year the British government has, according to media reports in August, increased its supply of arms to Egypt after reducing them following the 2013 ouster of Islamist president Mohamed Morsi.
The Campaign Against the Arms Trade (CAAT) reported that UK government records show that in the first quarter of 2015 London approved military licences to Egypt for "components of military combat vehicles", which suggests the UK sold such vehicles to Egypt.
The equipment was worth $75.8 million, representing a year-on-year increase of 30 times, after the first quarter of 2014 had military deals between the nations worth just $2.5 million.
